definition[0]: to make the inside of a room, house etc clean or tidy
example[0]: We’d better clean out the attic this week.
definition[1]: if something expensive cleans you out, you spend so much money on it that you now have very little left
example[1]: Our trip to Paris cleaned me out.
definition[2]: to steal everything from a place, or all of someone’s possessions
definition[3]: to take all the money of a person or organization
example[2]: The 16 bankrupt financial institutions threatened to clean out the central bank’s reserves.
definition[4]: to improve an organization by removing parts or people that are not making money or are not effective or honest
example[3]: The banks must restructure to cut costs and clean out portfolios that are full of bad loans.
definition[5]: when an organization is improved by removing parts or people that are not making money or are not effective or honest
example[4]: The country needs a clean-out of the balance sheets of its industrial companies.
